DOC.HEAD: Cheney Confirms `Stealth' Planes Dropped Bombs On Panama
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Advanced-technology ``stealth'' jets slipped through Panamanian air defenses and dropped two 2,000-pound bombs on a military base in the early hours of the U.S. invasion, said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Cheney told a Monday news conference in Panama that the raid before dawn Wednesday was intended to ``stun and disorient'' the Panamanian Defense Forces at Rio Hato before airborne troops were dropped there. The troops attacked an officers' school and base of the Machos de Monte battalion, one of deposed Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's crack units. The raid, first reported by a Pentagon spokesman on Saturday, was the first combat use of the F-117A fighter jet that employs ``stealth'' technology designed to elude radar. To date, the super-secret fighter built by the Lockheed Corp. has been kept from public viewing, with a squadron based in Nevada. A photograph of the plane released by the Pentagon last year depicts a relatively small swept-wing plane with a flat underbelly. From some angles it looks like a stingray. Stealth technology makes extensive use of exotic composite materials, some of which absorb rather than reflect radar waves, and avoids sharp surface angles. Cheney refused to elaborate on negotiations over Noriega, who is wanted in the United States on drug trafficking charges. Noriega sought refuge Sunday in the Vatican Embassy. ``It is U.S. policy that we would like to see Noriega brought for trial,'' he said, adding that the military's role in the hunt for the general had ended and ``now it is up to diplomats and lawyers.'' Cheney said he met with President Guillermo Endara and vice presidents Ricardo Arias Calderon and Guillermo Ford and was ``tremendously impressed with their determination to get the government of Panama back on its feet.'' He would not say what they talked about. Cheney also said U.S. troops had discovered a larger supply of Cuban weapons in Panama than they did during the American invasion of Grenada six years ago. ``It is sure far more weaponry was found than Mr. Noriega could conceivably use even if he armed his forces several times over,'' Cheney said. ``I'm not sure what the purpose of this is.'' Cheney said additional troops sent for the invasion ``will stay as long as they are needed. ... We don't want to leave too soon before the objective has been achieved.'' Cheney noted that the United States does not turn over the Panama Canal for 10 more years and said, ``There were troops here before so there will continue to be a U.S. military presence for the near future. The defense secretary visited troops earlier Monday and called the invasion ``the most surgical operation of its size ever carried out, not only by our forces but by anybody else's forces.''
